## Chapter 2: India, oh India!

> na gacchati vinƒÅ pƒÅna·πÉ vyƒÅdhirau·π£adha≈õabdata·∏• |
> vinƒÅparok·π£ƒÅnubhava·πÉ brahma≈õabdairna mucyate ||

> A disease is not cured if one simply utters the name of the medicine,
> without taking it. Similarly, without direct realization,
> one cannot be liberated merely by uttering the word ‚ÄúBrahman.‚Äù

> Vivekachudamani 64

As many did, I, too, have turned my eyes to India. At least I did it at the beginning of my search. Maybe it was because I was disappointed with the apparent disregard for anything subjective in the field of science. I didn't like the goddess of objectivity too much. I never grasp that concept fully; namely, everything people do is always subjective. The very idea of objectivity is so slippery that relying on it seems like a mission impossible. How to the hell can you hope to achieve objectivity when everything you know is utterly subjective?

We can only agree that something we perceive is the same for all of us and call it objective. In a sense, it is, but in a sense, it isn't. Remember VR? If ten players of a video game perceive the same virtual reality, can we call that perception an objective one? If one player has a particular bonus point and different clearance level at his disposal, thus seeing something others can't, is that perception objective? And what happens with the objectivity of the other nine?

You may say that the perception of all players is objective, but to call it true is an overstatement.

Of course, before computers came into our life, we didn't understand VR. But, somehow, sages from India made quite similar analogies using the dream state of consciousness. As we all know, dreams can be quite vivid. You can't doubt the experience inside the dream. We feel real fear; we are genuinely excited and happy; we can touch other people's skin and feel the warmth of their embrace. The feeling is authentic and based on something we perceive as entirely ‚Äûobjective‚Äú until we wake up. How impossible is the thought that the same thing happens right here, right now, inside the so-called ‚Äûwaking state of consciousness‚Äú?

Subjectivity is a reality; objectivity is a concept never to be achieved. You have to believe in it before you apply it to your life. And the belief was never my stronger side. I wanted to know, not to believe. If the truth is to be found, it must be found in the realm of subjectivity. Identifying the truth with objectivity is as good as saying that truth does not actually exist and that you can only believe in it.

Objectivity is a cuckoo's egg implanted through ideology. We cannot be sure that it even exists. On the other side, we can be sure that the truth exists. There must be something behind the illusion, something on top of what the illusion is built.

Somehow, I developed an early aversion to using the word objectivity. This aversion is not to be confused with trust in subjectivity. No way! Subjectivity is full of deceptions. So full that it became a synonym for it. But, in the end, it is all we have. And there, inside our experience, our consciousness ‚Äì at the place we call subjective - must be something we can identify as a true reality. What it is and how we can reach it, I didn't know.

I hoped that someone from India would know. More than that, I wished that someone would tell me how I could see it, understand it, and live it. That wish didn't come true, but the fascination with India had some advantages. Without it, I would not acquire a lot of precious and irreplaceable experiences of different, higher states of consciousness. And without that, I would have always wondered: what if. That doesn't mean that you have to take the same path. Quite the contrary, my point is that such experiences are overrated. But, I understand that if you are craving something different than the reality you are experiencing now, it isn't easy to accept that the change of experience is not an answer. Hearing such a statement can induce the same reaction as you would have when a wealthy person says that money is not important. Jim Carrey, a successful and famous actor, lately had an obvious turnover in his life. In one public speech, he said that he wishes for everyone to be successful and wealthy as he is, just to understand that the answers to perplexing questions in life cannot be bought with money. After hearing such a statement, your first thought may be: ‚ÄûYeah, right, for you, it is easy to say such a thing. You have money; you don't have to think about how to pay off your mortgage or university education for your children‚Äú. But, on the other hand, think about it: Jim Carrey has money, so maybe he knows what he is talking about. Perhaps you can believe him: he walked that path, and at its end, he says that money doesn't matter.

In the realm of spirituality, the currency is - experience. You are spiritually wealthy if you have enough experience. At least, that is what the majority of spiritual seekers consider relevant. What if (again, that stupid question!) someone spiritually wealthy would tell you that, at the end of the road, experience doesn't matter? You would not believe it, of course. Because what is there in spirituality, if not the experience? I understand; I wouldn't have believed in such nonsense if I had heard it forty years ago. Well, the truth is that I didn't hear it. I didn't have anyone to tell me that my search for a more profound experience of reality (whatever that may be) didn't matter. It may be fun, though, and much more interesting than pursuing the money, but still, it isn't so relevant for finding the truth about you and the world you are living in. I will return to that point in some of the later chapters, but for now, I want to inform you where I am coming from.

I have spent more than twenty years exploring techniques of meditation. For months, and on two occasions for years, I lived like a hermit and didn't do anything except dive into the deepness of my consciousness. I am pleased with my experiences, and even now, I wouldn't change them for anything. They include abiding inner peace; detachment from emotional bondage and absence of desires; prolonged experiences of witnessing not only worldly affairs but my own doings and even thoughts; clear perception of unmovable inner Self, the Atman, as they call it in India; development of exceptional powers like understanding the intention of speechless creatures, animals and such, occasional levitation, transfer of consciousness into other bodies, and similar. I gained profound insights into the mechanics of the development of consciousness, its stages, and especially its higher states. Those insights were not only intellectual but experiential, too. I could see different planes of reality, sometimes communicate with spiritual beings, visit other lokas (worlds) in dreams, and astral travels. I've seen and felt many wonders the majority of people never would.

When it comes to such experiences, it is usually much better to be silent than to tell and be misunderstood. I am quite tacit about it because I don't like the look of disbelief on other people's faces. Equally, maybe even more, I don't like the look of astonishment or admiration. Thus, my usual attitude is that I should stay in my separate world and not mingle too much with others.

But now I have a point to make. And that point is that, at the end of the road, I know that spiritual experience will not remove the question of ‚Äûwhat if.‚Äú You can always ask: ‚ÄûWhat if all that belongs to the illusion? What if these experiences are inside, like safe and exciting bubbles in the ocean of deception?‚Äú

How would you know?

The answer is devastating: as long as you are in the realm of experiences, you will never know.

After a long journey filled with difficulties, sacrifices, intensive feelings, breaking of the rules, and going against the stream; the journey in which despair and hope were mixed in unpredictable proportions with pure joy, I came to a point where the wall between me and what I was looking for became so thick, so impenetrable, that I had to stop. There was no going forward anymore. There were two options ahead: to quit and forget all about ‚Äûwhat if ‚Äú or to find another path. I knew: if I was to take the second option, the new way must be different ‚Äì radically different from everything I was doing until now.

I didn't abandon the search. Instead, I turned my back to India. I have seen a lot of it, but all I have seen was not enough for a breakthrough. I was not holding any grudge against it, and I didn't regret anything that I had done. I didn't feel that I had lost time in a futile search. Quite the contrary, in my mind, India has become like a memory of an exciting love story from my youth. I have grown since then; I learned a lot, and I was ready to move forward.

To illustrate, I didn't abandon the knowledge I acquired. I am still delighted to teach people meditation. The skill of naturally silencing the mind is precious. Modern people don't know how to relax, how to remove the excess stress. The need for activating unused inner potential is greater than ever.

Moreover, the experiences of higher states of consciousness are quite useful. If you have them, you can become much more efficient in whatever you aspire to achieve. Besides, it can be magically fun to explore hidden realms in the depths of your consciousness. I will always recommend everyone to take some time off of their life and dive deep into it.

However, I have no other choice but to warn you: despite the fun and usefulness, in the end, you will hit the wall. The final step over the line that separates the illusion from the truth cannot be made using the experience as a vehicle. Let me point you to the problem you will face.

Let's call that final step enlightenment. That word is overused, misused, and utterly unclear. However, in the absence of better wording, let's use it. (Other choices could include liberation or Sanskrit moksha; or abiding state of truth, which is precise but quite a mouthful.)

Look at the following sentences:

I am dreaming.
I am awake.
I am in a higher state of consciousness.
I am enlightened.

The first three are correct and meaningful; they are saying: I have experience.

The last one is wrong. It doesn't do justice to the final step over the line. At the beginning of the search, you don't see the difference ‚Äì it is all the same to you. You want to experience what is now not accessible to you. But, for the final crossing, it doesn't work that way. It works all the way up to the highest state of consciousness, but no further.

India gave me experience, and sure, I can teach the how of that experience to anyone who wants to learn it. But the final step is a different story. So, I had to do it alone, without India's ‚Äûburden‚Äú of India.

The burden is in quotes because it doesn't have to be a burden, just as anything you have learned otherwise doesn't have to be an obstacle to finding the truth. However, it usually is.

It is human nature to create beliefs, convictions, patterns, and standards. We like to drive on auto-pilot; once we are convinced that something or someone is right, we don't question too much what follows. In other words, we surrender our power of discrimination to someone or something we believe in. It happens all the time in your life. You give your discrimination power to the person you love, politicians you vote for, and a sexy lady who sells car tires. So, nothing new here, but Indian systems of spiritual teachings are notorious for taking that power from their followers.

In most cases, you are asked to believe and to surrender. India is full of Gurus and the people who believe them. That is a thousand-year-long tradition. Don't touch that. You cannot doubt something that comes from tradition. It's blasphemy.

Most of the followers from the West are just changing one auto-pilot for the other. They got tired and became disappointed with their way of life and wanted to switch to another. They bite the bait of different experiences. And they get what they want. Plus, a push into a more profound illusion. However, if they keep at least some of their common sense, instead of fascinating experiences calling for a wannabe spiritualist from another continent, they will see the blind spots amid the Indian spiritual circus ‚Äî gaps and holes, direct pointings at the truth. You may find them in scriptures but also in the speeches of those who present themselves as gurus, but in reality, they are just parrots.

The example of such holes may be the following sentences: the final step is always made by yourself, not with the help of anyone else; the scriptures amount to nothing if there is no living practice; the truth is eternal and everpresent - thus it doesn't need any guardian, and it is on everyone disposal if they are willing to take it, etc. Looking at these statements (I will return to them with much more details in later chapters) with the innocent eyes, you will see that they are in sharp contradiction with the requirements for following the tradition, surrender, belief, and faith. Of course, the advocates of these institutions will always try to convince you of the opposite. Your best defense is common sense.

It may be that I was just lucky, or it was the fact that I was headed towards the exit from my youth long before I discovered India. Whatever the reason, I never fell for a show. I did listen to what the teachers were saying, and I did what they suggested (or ordered) me to do. But I kept my sanity. Maybe it was unfortunate because I might be happier if I didn't.

Despite my decision that there was nothing for me from the side of India, India kept popping out! That didn't help at the time when I was crossing the line. I took it as an exciting twist of fate - a noncoincidental coincidence, but it didn't add anything to the pace of passing through the gateless gate. Only later, when the period of adjustment was over, did I notice that despite all shortcomings, India has to offer valuable insights even for the final exit. Those insights are hidden behind the colorful scenography, but they are there, nevertheless.

One of these valuable ideas, hidden under the enormous piles of garbage, is an idea that a discriminative power of your mind can take you over - from the world of illusion to the world of the truth. That power is called viveka. And indeed, it is the voice of the inner guru. I listened to that voice and used viveka to break through finally. Or break true, if you would like. I didn't know the word viveka then; I discovered it later with some lost and misinterpreted scriptures from Indian spiritual tradition. Basically, viveka is just ordinary common sense but applied literary and without compromise.

Not counting strange syntagmas as ‚Äûviveka yoga‚Äú mostly related to some traditional interpretation of viveka added to asanas and hatha yoga practices, you will find no trace of living viveka. If you are studying Sanskrit grammar, you may come across some parts of viveka describing discriminative factors (laskhanas). Still, it is far from any practical use in eliminating the power of illusion. All attempts to fight that power were restricted to experience. Tempting and apparently logical but not correct.

The supreme authority on viveka should be one well-known scripture attributed to Indian sage Adi Shankara. The title of that scripture is Vivekachudamani. However, as you will see, Vivekachudamani is a prime example of corrupted knowledge. Its diamonds are overlooked even though they are in plain sight.

A funny thing happened. India could not take me over the final line, but after I somehow managed to do just that, I like to spend my pastime describing the path leading out of the dark jungle grown upon mistakes of our minds. And, lo and behold, India is still offering inspiration! Strange, isn't it?

\*\*\*

title: Recover from superblock corrupted of BtrFS
body:
I‚Äôm have been using ***[UTM](https://mac.getutm.app/)*** as the virtualization platform on my Mac OS, it‚Äôs free and easy to use, it supports multiple hypervisors including QEMU, I chose QEMU 7.1 to run OpenSUSE TW with BtrFS as a guest OS, and I just encountered a superblock failure two days ago, the VM guest failed to boot up, there is only cursor flashing all the time on black screen when the guest was being restarting after a forced reboot and never going to Grub menu.

It remains black screen still after I tried multiple times, I was not aware that this error is acutally ***superblock*** of the BtrFS partition on /dev/vda2 corrupted until I saw the installation process warned me about this when I tried to reinstall the OS, then I tried to search how to fix superblock and I just found below instruction from this *[link](https://www.linuxbabe.com/desktop-linux/fix-cant-read-superblock-error)*:

`sudo btrfs rescue super-recover -v /dev/vda2`

I run it in rescue mode that I booted into by loading the installation ISO, it shows how many bytes are good and bad respectively, after running the rescue instruction successfully there is no bad byte numbers displayed anymore, I tried to boot up again then the Grub menu came back and booting to TW succeeded!

*My day was saved! :)*

title: Creating Morphing Animations with CSS
body:
Learn how to implement morphing using CSS, a technique for transforming one appearance into another.

### What is morphing?

Morphing is a technique where you transform one appearance into another. It‚Äôs a shape-shifting animation where a two-dimensional object, say an image or a figure or similar, turns into a different shape.

In this article for simplicity, we create a div that alternates between a square and a circle.

Define a div element with spinner class. Give the spinner basic demotions and animate it with a custom animation named Morph that takes 2 seconds and runs forever. 
  

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oMHCCazcqkLDetSYzsTVq.png?height=179&width=640)

 
  
 To make the element change its shape we need to define a custom animation named Morph. When the Morph animation is in 0 and 100 present, we set the border radius to 50% so the element shapes like a circle, and we set the border-radius to 0 when the animation is at 50% so it changes back to square.

Next, let's rotate the element and change its color during shape-shifting to give it a nice look. To do that we need to set the background color for each step and add a transform property that rotates the element between 0 and 180 degrees during animation steps. 
 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/c7Px_5Jr-sC19i2yTf1gu.png?height=368&width=644)

 
 Finally, our morphing animation works and you can see and play with the final code at nexuscode.online

title: BuildL with KNN3 in ETH Shanghai: Finding Your New Web3 Friends in MetaMail
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/lJknPFsrVU5BE6ZyvlSdH.jpg?height=982&width=1990)

MetaMail([metamail.ink](https://metamail.ink)) is the web3 email service provider. With MetaMail users use wallet/ENS as an Email address (e.g. suneal.eth@mmail.ink), and sign/encrypt emails to ensure security. MetaMail is compatible with other mail like Gmail. All those features are totally free.

### BuildL with KNN3 in ETH Shanghai

To encourage users to find more friends, we are using KNN3's recommendation service during ETH Shanghai Hackathon. KNN3 provides a set of recommendation algorithms and we choose JACCARD currently. Users can click the **Discover** tab to find their potential friends and send emails to them.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/nGBYHv38LqPZ1E3lExFEL.png?height=662&width=770)

KNN3 provides a powerful yet easy-to-use service. The best part is that the recommendation algorithm is pluggable, and new recommendation methods can be used in the future as the project develops, or as the user prefers.

**Future Perspective / Roadmap**

In the future, MetaMail will:

* Support address of Layer2 and some other chains.
* Show ENS as an address, and NFT as an avatar.
* Use KNN3 Network to empower social attributes.

**About MetaMail**

MetaMail([metamail.ink](https://metamail.ink)) is the web3 email service provider.

KNN3 Network is a Web3 Relationship aggregator on multi-blockchains. They are empowering web3 social discovery & user enabling.

KNN3 Network is a Web3¬† building block and data infrastructure which can be applied in tremendous Web3 native scenarios and provides a composable and optimizable graph solution with seamless synchronization from multi-blockchains.

title: Git Commands
body:
Git is a prevalent version control system ( VCS ) used by most programmers. In this blog, I am going to share some tips with basic commands to make using git easier.

To start with git, we need to understand how things work locally on the system while using git. 
 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TJgQtWHAeXnUFtEECIqrE.png?height=111&width=571)

This diagram will help to understand, what actually happens while using git locally. Starting with the working area, the working area is where the files that are not handled by git, it is the place where all the untracked files are kept. Staging area has files that are going to be part of the next commit. The repository contains all the project commits. Using the repository we can have files as it was at some point in time. 
  
 Git Commands:

### 1. Initializing git in your directory

The very first step that you need to do is to initialize the repository. 
  
 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/JsAXe8LjbCsQkKOcI1xP2.png?height=75&width=639)

### 2. git config

This command helps you to set the username and user email address to be used with your commits respectively. 
  
 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/DtmoGLQPyBo383-UGFf1R.png?height=92&width=603)

### 3. git status

This command is used to see the state of the working area and staging area. 
  
 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xTCq7kM9jyEiR3udEOUKe.png?height=71&width=639)

### 3. git add

This command is used to add files to the staging area.

To take all the files that are untracked in the working area to the staging area, we use:

title: the W block
body:
*This article was written to explore a question: what difference can web3 bring to CONTENT?*

# Web3 could bring a new experience.

### Block ID: Each piece of content carries a relationship

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0AkKsWptw9WYNRZ_UNKVE.png?height=2152&width=7352)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/m9HqJyYoJRGYzCyFswJxR.png?height=1624&width=3432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B1mprukzqTiy8h4yJ_BxC.png?height=1624&width=3432)

### Bi-directional linking capability

The introduction of bi-directional links is for bridging web2 ***context*** with web 3 ***id-ized*** ***content***. The concern is that the original and majority of the context is still on web2 pages(URLs), and the content we abstract from that context could have a *parallel* ‚Äúidentity(ID)‚Äú enabled by web3 infrastructure.

Later, we could do things like block mapping and text computation on IPFS(probably not on IPFS, but some middle layer for semantic computing), while the context are addressable on web 2.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ksZKVy79HlzEM_VoJhaJZ.png?height=2152&width=6472)

Treat every piece of content as an object, we could have a fresher and more interactive relationship with the content. Imagine you are building ‚Äúthe block website‚Äú!

This üëÜthinking stems from a missing experience. For a long time I suffered from repeatedly OCR (optical character recognition), PDF highlights, web pages (URLs) clips,‚Ä¶etc from separate medium. And then to make it ‚Äúin one place‚Äú, i become a tester & expert of TOOLs, i tried so many note-taking tools, plug-ins, and their corresponding plug-ins‚Ä¶and

You‚Äôd better not change your software, lose the PDF or anything, otherwise things are too tough to think aboutü§Ø. Mediums never exist as "objects" with ‚Äúus(objects)‚Äù, we are trying to organize them until realizing they are *dandelion*.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_IGfFdqjCMeZ_vtKhIEQp.png?height=481&width=780)

Simply put, can I do it once (cOpy, highlight, clip, cut,generate) and these things can follow "me" ?

So the question is, how do I *operate* on the content itself, and establish a relationship with it?

## A product idea_ ((W block))

### Proof of text via wallet signature.

From the beginning, whatever text you generate is under your signature.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/WURn7nsn5DvrA2cRS7D2-.png?height=2152&width=3176)

### Text generation with ease

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/snqQrWXVSVZMdiTJya2Q3.png?height=2152&width=3176)

Whenever you generate text, either note-taking or clipping content with its context, you can easily keep that in word blocks.

### Easy to reference on any editor

Take mirror for example,

1\. You can pull up the plugin at any time to see the previously saved blocks

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8yBUmnCNW7CAnvVojzc0B.png?height=2152&width=6448)

2\.  Copy the *block ID* (with bidirectional links)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2vbYP5IKoHHHdCSsFasL2.png?height=2152&width=3176)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Wh0v4bE0IGwuL6DaNKL-x.png?height=2152&width=6456)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/PlDqTO85qArWrZgMCwraO.png?height=2152&width=6472)

3\. For readers, jump directly to the specific part of the web page (like scroll-to-text)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wLxi0odSlK8PAOth59r_t.png?height=2152&width=6488)

## Search

As you see, as we accumulate a ***block network*** of text, a semantic network needs to be constructed for ***block search***.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HhxjT2Tnv9HxPZurNQpBY.png?height=3796&width=7966)

Thoughts for the Block Network üï∏Ô∏è :

* Create a set of intermediaries (e.g., a group of people taking notes)
* Store the semantic relations of blocks on a network of these intermediaries
* spend up the retrieval of blocks (either yours or others' can be queried) keywords/categories/time/factors

## Last but not least

Like i mentioned in the post, word block aims to explore a new experience between **content** and **individuals**, but in essence, it is still the relationship between people, between like-minded people.

1st, where we stand is the **signature economy** instead of an Information silos, we connect via open creation under MY signature.

2nd, "social" has a vivid landscape in web3, where people could be matched to each other for various purposes. if word block is a **literature system**, there will be ‚Äúdrivers‚Äú helping match "words" or thoughts.

when people want to find similar "blocks", refer to each other's block, and be united by block curation, that's the kind of "social" via block-based knowledge graph!

3rd, I want to connect the web2 context(the existing literature history) with the web3 capability of composability, computability, and interoperability (make a parallel new world of things). I summarize as:

*Dismantle web page,
present in blocks,
match via blocks.*

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/y4bmaRW8fEkxQiG5rQqh_.gif?height=1176&width=1246)

title: the W block
body:
*This article was written to explore a question: what difference can web3 bring to CONTENT?*

# Web3 could bring a new experience.

### Block ID: Each piece of content carries a relationship

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0AkKsWptw9WYNRZ_UNKVE.png?height=2152&width=7352)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/m9HqJyYoJRGYzCyFswJxR.png?height=1624&width=3432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B1mprukzqTiy8h4yJ_BxC.png?height=1624&width=3432)

### Bi-directional linking capability

The introduction of bi-directional links is for bridging web2 ***context*** with web 3 ***id-ized*** ***content***. The concern is that the original and majority of the context is still on web2 pages(URLs), and the content we abstract from that context could have a *parallel* ‚Äúidentity(ID)‚Äú enabled by web3 infrastructure.

Later, we could do things like block mapping and text computation on IPFS(probably not on IPFS, but some middle layer for semantic computing), while the context are addressable on web 2.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ksZKVy79HlzEM_VoJhaJZ.png?height=2152&width=6472)

Treat every piece of content as an object, we could have a fresher and more interactive relationship with the content. Imagine you are building ‚Äúthe block website‚Äú!

This üëÜthinking stems from a missing experience. For a long time I suffered from repeatedly OCR (optical character recognition), PDF highlights, web pages (URLs) clips,‚Ä¶etc from separate medium. And then to make it ‚Äúin one place‚Äú, i become a tester & expert of TOOLs, i tried so many note-taking tools, plug-ins, and their corresponding plug-ins‚Ä¶and

You‚Äôd better not change your software, lose the PDF or anything, otherwise things are too tough to think aboutü§Ø. Mediums never exist as "objects" with ‚Äúus(objects)‚Äù, we are trying to organize them until realizing they are *dandelion*.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_IGfFdqjCMeZ_vtKhIEQp.png?height=481&width=780)

Simply put, can I do it once (cOpy, highlight, clip, cut,generate) and these things can follow "me" ?

So the question is, how do I *operate* on the content itself, and establish a relationship with it?

## A product idea_ ((W block))

### Proof of text via wallet signature.

From the beginning, whatever text you generate is under your signature.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/WURn7nsn5DvrA2cRS7D2-.png?height=2152&width=3176)

### Text generation with ease

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/snqQrWXVSVZMdiTJya2Q3.png?height=2152&width=3176)

Whenever you generate text, either note-taking or clipping content with its context, you can easily keep that in word blocks.

### Easy to reference on any editor

Take mirror for example,

1\. You can pull up the plugin at any time to see the previously saved blocks

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8yBUmnCNW7CAnvVojzc0B.png?height=2152&width=6448)

2\.  Copy the *block ID* (with bidirectional links)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2vbYP5IKoHHHdCSsFasL2.png?height=2152&width=3176)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Wh0v4bE0IGwuL6DaNKL-x.png?height=2152&width=6456)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/PlDqTO85qArWrZgMCwraO.png?height=2152&width=6472)

3\. For readers, jump directly to the specific part of the web page (like scroll-to-text)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wLxi0odSlK8PAOth59r_t.png?height=2152&width=6488)

## Search

As you see, as we accumulate a ***block network*** of text, a semantic network needs to be constructed for ***block search***.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HhxjT2Tnv9HxPZurNQpBY.png?height=3796&width=7966)

Thoughts for the Block Network üï∏Ô∏è :

* Create a set of intermediaries (e.g., a group of people taking notes)
* Store the semantic relations of blocks on a network of these intermediaries
* spend up the retrieval of blocks (either yours or others' can be queried) keywords/categories/time/factors

## Last but not least

Like i mentioned in the post, word block aims to explore a new experience between **content** and **individuals**, but in essence, it is still the relationship between people, between like-minded people.

1st, where we stand is the **signature economy** instead of an Information silos, we connect via open creation under MY signature.

2nd, "social" has a vivid landscape in web3, where people could be matched to each other for various purposes. if word block is a **literature system**, there will be ‚Äúdrivers‚Äú helping match "words" or thoughts.

when people want to find similar "blocks", refer to each other's block, and be united by block curation, that's the kind of "social" via block-based knowledge graph!

3rd, I want to connect the web2 context(the existing literature history) with the web3 capability of composability, computability, and interoperability (make a parallel new world of things). I summarize as:

*Dismantle web page,
present in blocks,
match via blocks.*

title: A step by step guide to create a token with Encentive
body:
Click Have you ever wanted to create a token of your own? And it seemed like it was impossible to do so? I am here to let you know, that it is totally possible with Encentive

Encentive makes anyone be able to create any token with just a few clicks and I will be guiding you on how to go about it,

### A step-by-step guide to creating a token using Encentive:

* Visit- [encentive.io](https://encentive.io)
* 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Zpcu570DBR_l1erAyXuCG.png?height=860&width=1917)

Click on the dapp icon on the home page, as seen in the image above, and wait for it to load.

* 

![Click on the highlighted icon](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8W6j9o0uao73QCO6EdIcO.png?height=823&width=1614)

Click on the yellowish highlighted icon to switch between any chain you wish to create a token on.

Then connect your wallet to the dapp.

* 

![Click on the highlighted icon](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/QeQIdIIQG12yuntIQ9eTf.png?height=807&width=1614)

Click on the Create token icon, to begin your journey, remember to approve the transaction through your metamask extension. 

Remember to keep some tokens depending on the blockchain for gas fee.

* 

![Fill in token info](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KQUKbcDBNBqC4FVA5DhmY.png?height=831&width=1865)

All you will have to do on this page is fill in some basic information about your token.

Once you are done, click on the Create icon and then approve the transaction.

* 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TW-nF9N0nPVp0TpABTVKh.png?height=625&width=1869)

Your created token will look like the one in the picture above.

You can then proceed to explore other options on the Encentive Dapp. Such as creating a liquidity pool etc.

* To get the contract address of your token, depending on the blockchain, go to its scan e.g [bscscan.com](https://bscscan.com), and scan your wallet address.
*  

![A token I created](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U0XH2Lm5hq2WJOw5uwHPt.png?height=468&width=1853)

The picture above shows the token I created using Encentive. 

Yours should be the same too depending on the parameters you filled in.

### As stated earlier, Encentive makes it very easy to create a token with few clicks. Create that token today.

title: the W block
body:
*This article was written to explore a question: what difference can web3 bring to CONTENT?*

# Web3 could bring a new experience.

### Block ID: Each piece of content carries a relationship

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0AkKsWptw9WYNRZ_UNKVE.png?height=2152&width=7352)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/m9HqJyYoJRGYzCyFswJxR.png?height=1624&width=3432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B1mprukzqTiy8h4yJ_BxC.png?height=1624&width=3432)

### Bi-directional linking capability

The introduction of bi-directional links is for bridging web2 ***context*** with web 3 ***id-ized*** ***content***. The concern is that the original and majority of the context is still on web2 pages(URLs), and the content we abstract from that context could have a *parallel* ‚Äúidentity(ID)‚Äú enabled by web3 infrastructure.

Later, we could do things like block mapping and text computation on IPFS(probably not on IPFS, but some middle layer for semantic computing), while the context are addressable on web 2.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ksZKVy79HlzEM_VoJhaJZ.png?height=2152&width=6472)

Treat every piece of content as an object, we could have a fresher and more interactive relationship with the content. Imagine you are building ‚Äúthe block website‚Äú!

This üëÜthinking stems from a missing experience. For a long time I suffered from repeatedly OCR (optical character recognition), PDF highlights, web pages (URLs) clips,‚Ä¶etc from separate medium. And then to make it ‚Äúin one place‚Äú, i become a tester & expert of TOOLs, i tried so many note-taking tools, plug-ins, and their corresponding plug-ins‚Ä¶and

You‚Äôd better not change your software, lose the PDF or anything, otherwise things are too tough to think aboutü§Ø. Mediums never exist as "objects" with ‚Äúus(objects)‚Äù, we are trying to organize them until realizing they are *dandelion*.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_IGfFdqjCMeZ_vtKhIEQp.png?height=481&width=780)

Simply put, can I do it once (cOpy, highlight, clip, cut,generate) and these things can follow "me" ?

So the question is, how do I *operate* on the content itself, and establish a relationship with it?

## A product idea_ ((W block))

### Proof of text via wallet signature.

From the beginning, whatever text you generate is under your signature.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/WURn7nsn5DvrA2cRS7D2-.png?height=2152&width=3176)

### Text generation with ease

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/snqQrWXVSVZMdiTJya2Q3.png?height=2152&width=3176)

Whenever you generate text, either note-taking or clipping content with its context, you can easily keep that in word blocks.

### Easy to reference on any editor

Take mirror for example,

1\. You can pull up the plugin at any time to see the previously saved blocks

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8yBUmnCNW7CAnvVojzc0B.png?height=2152&width=6448)

2\.  Copy the *block ID* (with bidirectional links)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2vbYP5IKoHHHdCSsFasL2.png?height=2152&width=3176)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Wh0v4bE0IGwuL6DaNKL-x.png?height=2152&width=6456)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/PlDqTO85qArWrZgMCwraO.png?height=2152&width=6472)

3\. For readers, jump directly to the specific part of the web page (like scroll-to-text)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wLxi0odSlK8PAOth59r_t.png?height=2152&width=6488)

## Search

As you see, as we accumulate a ***block network*** of text, a semantic network needs to be constructed for ***block search***.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HhxjT2Tnv9HxPZurNQpBY.png?height=3796&width=7966)

Thoughts for the Block Network üï∏Ô∏è :

* Create a set of intermediaries (e.g., a group of people taking notes)
* Store the semantic relations of blocks on a network of these intermediaries
* spend up the retrieval of blocks (either yours or others' can be queried) keywords/categories/time/factors

## Last but not least

Like i mentioned in the post, word block aims to explore a new experience between **content** and **individuals**, but in essence, it is still the relationship between people, between like-minded people.

1st, where we stand is the **signature economy** instead of an Information silos, we connect via open creation under MY signature.

2nd, "social" has a vivid landscape in web3, where people could be matched to each other for various purposes. if word block is a **literature system**, there will be ‚Äúdrivers‚Äú helping match "words" or thoughts.

when people want to find similar "blocks", refer to each other's block, and be united by block curation, that's the kind of "social" via block-based knowledge graph!

3rd, I want to connect the web2 context(the existing literature history) with the web3 capability of composability, computability, and interoperability (make a parallel new world of things). I summarize as:

*Dismantle web page,
present in blocks,
match via blocks.*

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/y4bmaRW8fEkxQiG5rQqh_.gif?height=1176&width=1246)

title: A step by step guide to create a token with Encentive
body:
Click Have you ever wanted to create a token of your own? And it seemed like it was impossible to do so? I am here to let you know, that it is totally possible with Encentive

Encentive makes anyone be able to create any token with just a few clicks and I will be guiding you on how to go about it,

### A step-by-step guide to creating a token using Encentive:

* Visit- [encentive.io](https://encentive.io)
* 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Zpcu570DBR_l1erAyXuCG.png?height=860&width=1917)

Click on the dapp icon on the home page, as seen in the image above, and wait for it to load.

* 

![Click on the highlighted icon](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8W6j9o0uao73QCO6EdIcO.png?height=823&width=1614)

Click on the yellowish highlighted icon to switch between any chain you wish to create a token on.

Then connect your wallet to the dapp.

* 

![Click on the highlighted icon](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/QeQIdIIQG12yuntIQ9eTf.png?height=807&width=1614)

Click on the Create token icon, to begin your journey, remember to approve the transaction through your metamask extension. 

Remember to keep some tokens depending on the blockchain for gas fee.

* 

![Fill in token info](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KQUKbcDBNBqC4FVA5DhmY.png?height=831&width=1865)

All you will have to do on this page is fill in some basic information about your token.

Once you are done, click on the Create icon and then approve the transaction.

* 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TW-nF9N0nPVp0TpABTVKh.png?height=625&width=1869)

Your created token will look like the one in the picture above.

You can then proceed to explore other options on the Encentive Dapp. Such as creating a liquidity pool etc.

* To get the contract address of your token, depending on the blockchain, go to its scan e.g [bscscan.com](https://bscscan.com), and scan your wallet address.
*  

![A token I created](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U0XH2Lm5hq2WJOw5uwHPt.png?height=468&width=1853)

The picture above shows the token I created using Encentive. 

Yours should be the same too depending on the parameters you filled in.

### As stated earlier, Encentive makes it very easy to create a token with few clicks. Create that token today.

title: A step-by-step guide to creating a token with Encentive
body:
Click Have you ever wanted to create a token of your own? And it seemed like it was impossible to do so? I am here to let you know, that it is totally possible with Encentive

Encentive makes anyone be able to create any token with just a few clicks and I will be guiding you on how to go about it,

### A step-by-step guide to creating a token using Encentive:

* Visit- [encentive.io](https://encentive.io)
* 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Zpcu570DBR_l1erAyXuCG.png?height=860&width=1917)

Click on the dapp icon on the home page, as seen in the image above, and wait for it to load.

* 

![Click on the highlighted icon](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8W6j9o0uao73QCO6EdIcO.png?height=823&width=1614)

Click on the yellowish highlighted icon to switch between any chain you wish to create a token on.

Then connect your wallet to the dapp.

* 

![Click on the highlighted icon](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/QeQIdIIQG12yuntIQ9eTf.png?height=807&width=1614)

Click on the Create token icon, to begin your journey, remember to approve the transaction through your metamask extension. 

Remember to keep some tokens depending on the blockchain for gas fee.

* 

![Fill in token info](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KQUKbcDBNBqC4FVA5DhmY.png?height=831&width=1865)

All you will have to do on this page is fill in some basic information about your token.

Once you are done, click on the Create icon and then approve the transaction.

* 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TW-nF9N0nPVp0TpABTVKh.png?height=625&width=1869)

Your created token will look like the one in the picture above.

You can then proceed to explore other options on the Encentive Dapp. Such as creating a liquidity pool etc.

* To get the contract address of your token, depending on the blockchain, go to its scan e.g [bscscan.com](https://bscscan.com), and scan your wallet address.
*  

![A token I created](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U0XH2Lm5hq2WJOw5uwHPt.png?height=468&width=1853)

The picture above shows the token I created using Encentive. 

Yours should be the same too depending on the parameters you filled in.

### As stated earlier, Encentive makes it very easy to create a token with few clicks. Create that token today.

title: 7 GitHub projects essential for every Javascript developer  üöÄ
body:
Javascript is so widely adopted that most developers can't avoid it entirely during the course of their careers. Sooner or later, you need to face JS, and when you do, you need to be ready with practical and fundamental concepts of the Javascript programming language.

So today, I want to share 7 amazing GitHub projects that will help you become a better Javascript developer. These GitHub projects are quite popular and can be a go-to resource for anyone looking to learn, and let's face it - Devs are always learning.ü§ì

So let's get started. üëä


---

Currently building [SigNoz](https://bit.ly/3A6k4an) - an open-source application performance monitoring tool. The front-end is built in Typescript and Reactjs.

Check out our GitHub repoüëá 
  
 

[https://github.com/SigNoz/signoz](https://github.com/SigNoz/signoz)

## 1. You don't know JS

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 141k

This repo is a series of books on core mechanisms of the Javascript language. The 2nd edition of the series is currently in progress, while the first edition is available and is entirely free to read online! 
 

[https://github.com/getify/You-Dont-Know-JS](https://github.com/getify/You-Dont-Know-JS)

 
 2. Javascript Algorithms

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 111k

This repo is an amazing resource for anyone wanting to get a firm understanding of algorithms and data structure. It contains JavaScript based examples of many popular algorithms and data structures. 
  
 

[https://github.com/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms](https://github.com/trekhleb/javascript-algorithms)

 
 3. 30 seconds of code

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 78.1k

This repo can be a super-booster to your JS workflow. It contains short Javascript code snippets for all your development needs. Once you get used to this, there's no looking back.üôá‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 
  
 

[https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code)

## 4. Front-End Checklist

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 54.1k

There are a million things to take care of when you launch a website. So how do you ensure you have taken care of things that can break your product when it goes into production. Enter `Front-end Checklist`‚úÖ. It is an exhaustive list of all elements you need to have/test before launching your website / HTML page to production. 
  
 

[https://github.com/thedaviddias/Front-End-Checklist](https://github.com/thedaviddias/Front-End-Checklist)

[View on GitHub](https://github.com/thedaviddias/Front-End-Checklist)

## 5. Front End interview handbook

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 29.5k

This repo promises to make you go from zero to front-end interview hero even if you don't have prior interview experience. And, from the number of stargazers it has, it looks like it delivers on that promise. It has answers to every question in the very famous question bank **Front-end Job Interview Questions. 
  
 **

[https://github.com/yangshun/front-end-interview-handbook](https://github.com/yangshun/front-end-interview-handbook)

## 6. Web-Dev for Beginners

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 27.1k

This repo is maintained by Azure Cloud Advocates at Microsoft and offers a 12-week, 24-lesson curriculum all about JavaScript, CSS, and HTML basics. 
  
 

[https://github.com/microsoft/Web-Dev-For-Beginners](https://github.com/microsoft/Web-Dev-For-Beginners)

 
 7. Reactjs Interview Questions

> ‚≠ê Github stars: 14k

This repo has a list of top 500 ReactJS Interview Questions & Answers. 
  
 

[https://github.com/sudheerj/reactjs-interview-questions](https://github.com/sudheerj/reactjs-interview-questions)

 
  
 

[https://dev.to/ankit01oss/7-github-projects-essential-for-every-javascript-developer-258i](https://dev.to/ankit01oss/7-github-projects-essential-for-every-javascript-developer-258i)

title: Roe vs Wade and your period data - who is in control?
body:
**If you felt uneasy seeing the suspicious Instagram ad for car upholstery minutes after discussing it then have you considered how your health data can be leveraged in a post Roe vs Wade world?**

Like 43 million other people around the world I use Flo to monitor my periods. I use it because I like knowing more about my body, like when I can expect my period or why my face is having a throwback to 90s acne fashion.¬†

I also joined more than 290 million people in 2021 and bought myself a wearable. Not just any wearable, I wanted the Garmin sports watch that revealed data I‚Äôd never even heard of. I wanted so much data that I had to spend more time searching for metric definitions than reading the data itself.

I never take my watch off. I sleep with it on so I can use the data to inform how I should feel when I wake up. I have literally outsourced my feelings to technology.

Never did I once stop to think about how all this health data could be used against me. Akin to requesting my medical history, what is stopping my health insurance provider from requesting my watch data and what happens if I say no (can I even say no?).

Trawling Twitter I came across the [Mashable](https://mashable.com/article/period-apps-roe-v-wade) article *Period Apps in a Post-Roe World*. I was truly startled by the question - who owns my period data. I had never questioned it but now that data could be weaponised against women and I feel scared.¬†

I feel scared because we‚Äôve been indoctrinated into a world of technology and regulation as trusting.¬†

We‚Äôve blindly outsourced control and when it turned against us we assumed regulators and legislators could step in to rescue us. That has largely not worked. We‚Äôre disrupted by a variety of unstandardised data pop-ups at the most inopportune times that make saying no hard. Now we‚Äôre facing legislation that is removing choice altogether.

In 2011 South Park released HUMANCENTiPAD which depicts the bleakest of outcomes when we don‚Äôt read our T&Cs. After this, for the shortest time, I read my T&Cs but they‚Äôre very boring and the vernacular makes me feel stupid. It is unpleasant in enough ways that the memory of HUMANCENTiPAD dissipated and I went back to blind acceptance.¬†

In 2018 there was excitement around wearables as a tool to intercept medical emergencies amongst the elderly. The monitoring of wearable data could enable our elderly community to lead a more independent life. I loved it. I never once stopped to think about the paradox of independence through monitoring.

In 2020 an Australia court [forced Google](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/feb/14/court-says-melbourne-dentist-can-serve-google-for-user-details-over-bad-review) to reveal the identity of an anonymous user who left a negative review of a Dentistry, and in 2022 [forced Twitter](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jun/07/twitter-ordered-to-hand-over-prguy17s-personal-information-as-part-of-defamation-suit) to reveal the identity of a pseudonymous account following a defamation claim. I‚Äôm not convinced the everyday social user is aware that their personal data can be solicited in this way.

Bringing us back to 2022 and we have emerging technologies enabling trustless systems and sovereign identity. It is a momentous shift and people are not flocking to this new sense of control because it is scary AF. It is intended to feel complicated, full of codified language to keep laypeople out. If I‚Äôm worried about how the Australian Government can access my personal data I‚Äôm sure as hell not ready to consider a totally anonymous tech-fluent entity as the next best option.

It is hard not to hark back to South Park‚Äôs 2004 Douche and Turd episode. By that I mean we‚Äôre faced with less than ideal options and it can feel hopeless. By no means do I want people to feel that way. New technologies are not ready for full-on adoption and old technologies are so ingrained that total disconnection is near impossible.

Instead I say it is time we got a little curious about data storage. I think it is unreasonable to read all your T&Cs and a world without all this amazing technology would suck. But, you should know where your data is stored to understand what laws protect you as a user.

For example, if your data is stored in Europe, like the users of Flo, then you are protected by some of the most advanced digital and data legislation in the world such as GDPR and the Digital Services Act. At the very least get familiar with who makes the big decisions in your country and how that extends to you. For example, GDPR protects the processing of data for all EU residents regardless of where they live.

By knowing who governs your data and how apps can use it means you are more empowered to make choices that favour your rights. I implore you to take this small step towards control in our tech interfaced world. Start with the apps you use the most, the ones that know the most about you or access the most personal of your data.

Our internet is full of variety and choice, you can always find a better solution to suit all your needs including privacy. Or, if not build one. You as the user have the power and you don‚Äôt need to settle.

PS - if like me your T&Cs still scare you, or if you just watched HUMANCENTiPAD then <https://tosdr.org/> might come in handy.

title: I‚Äôm helping my algorithms get over my break-up
body:
My algorithms are going through a break up and they‚Äôre taking longer than I am to move on.

My Spotify Discover Weekly has been tainted with his music taste, a result of many nights exploring each other through music. My Release Radar is a lost cause, it is now solely focused on him like a jilted lover. My Instagram recommendations center on people he knows despite us no longer maintaining any social connection. Even my Google Maps continues to highlight the places we frequented despite my now total avoidance.

Break-ups are horrendous, whether the breaker or breakee there is a period of time where the sensation of losing that other person weighs on you. For me it was like being cast from a world so suddenly that real life felt foreign. A relationship during Covid moves fast, you burrow into each other‚Äôs existence without the disruption of the outside world.

We‚Äôd built an entire shared existence in almost isolation so when one half of this empire decided to break up the kingdom it was a shock. I spun, hit emotional rock bottom a few times and discovered new depths in desperation. I also bounced back.

However, my algorithms haven‚Äôt come along for the ride. I‚Äôm not sure they‚Äôve even noticed how much my life has changed. They seem stubbornly nostalgic. I do not want to forget my relationship, I just want to leave it where it is ‚Äî in the past. That was easy once, you could close that memory portal in your mind, remove physical reminders and focus on the present. Today our memories extend beyond our own mind to our data legacy, and that has proven harder to manage.

I‚Äôve taken to investing serious time in helping my algorithms move on. I‚Äôm trying to flush out their memory paths, reminding them what I do and don‚Äôt like. Revisiting old times so they can recall who I was before I met him. It is an unreal experience. There is no way to accelerate this without impacting my own data-driven experience which I appreciate and implore in today‚Äôs tech-centric lifestyle.

Each weekend I sit with Spotify and take distinct actions to signal what is mine and what is his. I‚Äôm Marie Kondoing my apps! I scoured my Instagram to rid my follower list of any remnants of his world to make the incessant suggestions stop. I‚Äôve moved on, I feel better but this is painful AF. It hurts to have these sensory reminders of a time I loved and lost, the visceral memories send my stomach plummeting. My algorithms are suffering through a lengthy recovery period and I‚Äôm scared they‚Äôre going to drag me back.

There is no easy solution, this is a growing problem as technology becomes the central way we interface with the world. How can we create empathy in something that is binary, how can we signal when we need to make an urgent change to the construct of our world to survive a painful experience. At the time of writing the only way to do it is a hard reset and why should I be burdened with rebuilding myself and my significant tech-others at the same time? One is hard enough, let alone the many-me‚Äôs that live in my apps and devices.

Our data shadow is growing and I can‚Äôt help but think it is creating a more distinct box, the past increasingly impacting our quest for new or different or diverse. We‚Äôre trading more for the convenience of predictability and data intelligence than we realise. So far the public discussion is focused in two areas, the spread of misinformation and the use of data for commercial gain.

While these are pertinent issues, we need to expand the narrative. The digital world is no longer divorced from the physical world, they are symbiotic. Digital platforms are playing a disproportionate role in the very fabric of our lives yet our ability to augment their control is limited ‚Äî opt-out or delete ‚Äî this is not how we live; we do not start afresh each time we face adversity, we adapt and move forward. I want to adapt my apps, I like them in my life but not when they can‚Äôt respect the dynamic person I am.

We need to keep reminding ourselves that in pursuit of a more intelligent world we are still human and we‚Äôve spent millennia building institutions to protect what is important to us. Let‚Äôs swing that same focus to our digital platforms who now hold considerable agency over our daily lives.

title: I‚Äôm helping my algorithms get over my break-up
body:
My algorithms are going through a break up and they‚Äôre taking longer than I am to move on.

My Spotify Discover Weekly has been tainted with his music taste, a result of many nights exploring each other through music. My Release Radar is a lost cause, it is now solely focused on him like a jilted lover. My Instagram recommendations center on people he knows despite us no longer maintaining any social connection. Even my Google Maps continues to highlight the places we frequented despite my now total avoidance.

Break-ups are horrendous, whether the breaker or breakee there is a period of time where the sensation of losing that other person weighs on you. For me it was like being cast from a world so suddenly that real life felt foreign. A relationship during Covid moves fast, you burrow into each other‚Äôs existence without the disruption of the outside world.

We‚Äôd built an entire shared existence in almost isolation so when one half of this empire decided to break up the kingdom it was a shock. I spun, hit emotional rock bottom a few times and discovered new depths in desperation. I also bounced back.

However, my algorithms haven‚Äôt come along for the ride. I‚Äôm not sure they‚Äôve even noticed how much my life has changed. They seem stubbornly nostalgic. I do not want to forget my relationship, I just want to leave it where it is ‚Äî in the past. That was easy once, you could close that memory portal in your mind, remove physical reminders and focus on the present. Today our memories extend beyond our own mind to our data legacy, and that has proven harder to manage.

I‚Äôve taken to investing serious time in helping my algorithms move on. I‚Äôm trying to flush out their memory paths, reminding them what I do and don‚Äôt like. Revisiting old times so they can recall who I was before I met him. It is an unreal experience. There is no way to accelerate this without impacting my own data-driven experience which I appreciate and implore in today‚Äôs tech-centric lifestyle.

Each weekend I sit with Spotify and take distinct actions to signal what is mine and what is his. I‚Äôm Marie Kondoing my apps! I scoured my Instagram to rid my follower list of any remnants of his world to make the incessant suggestions stop. I‚Äôve moved on, I feel better but this is painful AF. It hurts to have these sensory reminders of a time I loved and lost, the visceral memories send my stomach plummeting. My algorithms are suffering through a lengthy recovery period and I‚Äôm scared they‚Äôre going to drag me back.

There is no easy solution, this is a growing problem as technology becomes the central way we interface with the world. How can we create empathy in something that is binary, how can we signal when we need to make an urgent change to the construct of our world to survive a painful experience. At the time of writing the only way to do it is a hard reset and why should I be burdened with rebuilding myself and my significant tech-others at the same time? One is hard enough, let alone the many-me‚Äôs that live in my apps and devices.

Our data shadow is growing and I can‚Äôt help but think it is creating a more distinct box, the past increasingly impacting our quest for new or different or diverse. We‚Äôre trading more for the convenience of predictability and data intelligence than we realise. So far the public discussion is focused in two areas, the spread of misinformation and the use of data for commercial gain.

While these are pertinent issues, we need to expand the narrative. The digital world is no longer divorced from the physical world, they are symbiotic. Digital platforms are playing a disproportionate role in the very fabric of our lives yet our ability to augment their control is limited ‚Äî opt-out or delete ‚Äî this is not how we live; we do not start afresh each time we face adversity, we adapt and move forward. I want to adapt my apps, I like them in my life but not when they can‚Äôt respect the dynamic person I am.

We need to keep reminding ourselves that in pursuit of a more intelligent world we are still human and we‚Äôve spent millennia building institutions to protect what is important to us. Let‚Äôs swing that same focus to our digital platforms who now hold considerable agency over our daily lives.

title: #WenMerge EP.2: The Merge Starter Guide w/ Anthony Sassano & Tim Beiko
If you can be anyone, where do you start?
body:
I‚Äôm having an identity crisis.

The cataclysmic moment was creating my Bumble BFF profile. It is one thing to design your identity for dating ‚Äî pick the best photos, surface a cult-classic film, link your Spotify for street cred ‚Äî but when profiling for friends it isn‚Äôt that simple. Photos are part of your aesthetic but which me do I squeeze into 300 characters?! My sporty, health conscious self? My meandering bookstore self? My boozy brunch and bender self?

When they ask ‚Äúwrite something about yourself‚Äù I end up asking ‚Äúwho even am I?!‚Äù

I‚Äôm a chameleon.

It is hard to answer that question because I augment around my surroundings and influences. Mostly it means I live in happy harmony with the world around me and have a kaleidoscope of friends, influences, passions and interests. But, at times this leads me to an identity crisis and I have the distinct urge to rip it up and start afresh. Purge those that reflect too brightly my old self in search of something new and appealing.

Thank god for Facebook and Google‚Ä¶JOKES! I have not pledged allegiance to the almighty tech gods but it did get me thinking about the simplicity of a managed identity. One where I didn‚Äôt need to think. Identity is a complex concept, it can happen unnoticed as we go through life but unfurls when given focus.

If Facebook were a person, how would it describe you? Those cheeky Instagram stalks, archived WhatsApp chats and panicked DrGoogle searches all contribute to how your friend, Facebook, sees you. This is what we call ‚Äúfederated identity‚Äù, whereby all the factors that make up who we are including our late night sleuthing is stored and organised for the convenience of a consolidated identity.

Now, imagine having that power back. This is what we call ‚Äúself-sovereign identity‚Äù, and if we pare back the web3 chat it simply means you, not Facebook, are responsible for all that information about you. How it is used or not used is completely in your control. This means how the world sees you is more in your control than before because you are managing what is stored and how it is used. One way you do this is through a *wallet*. Just like your physical wallet that holds your driver‚Äôs licence, bank cards and loyalty cards but it‚Äôs digital.

This new era is akin to that wonderful time in Kindergarten, you‚Äôve been given a blank piece of paper and asked to draw who you want to be when you grow up. You have an infinite number of choices at your fingertips to primp and prune *you*. Do you relish the opportunity or are you paralysed with choice; do you look around at the other kids to see what they‚Äôre drawing or do you shy away so no one can see what you‚Äôre doing; do you proudly declare your masterpiece or roll-it up and put it away?

When I was drawing my future self I looked around, drew inspiration from those around me then in my characteristically competitive self went about trying to better or improve upon it. A little for bragging but mostly for group recognition. Where I started was largely dependent on the world around me. It gave me a foundation to start my drawing by narrowing my options.

Now we are in a time of infinite others to peer over, and infinite colouring pencils to choose from.

This new found identity freedom could feel daunting if not paralysing. There is no end point if identity is in part grounded by technology because of its progressive nature. There is an exponential growth in identity variables where before your options were narrowed by what was available and accessible.

Now we can unshackle self exploration and our identity from finite, binary categories or permanency. We can explore many nuances of ourselves, we can even create different *wallets* that hold different types of information to not confuse the different versions of you. We are creating multiple drawings, some stick figures and others Rembrandts, some to be stuck on the fridge and others just for us to enjoy.

We are happening upon an exciting time of self exploration and I‚Äôm coming through my crisis by realising I am not finished defining who I am. As a self-confessed chameleon I have many more communities and worlds to discover. Most importantly these worlds are expanding exponentially thanks to new technologies and quite naturally won‚Äôt always overlap or interact. Life is not lived in Venn diagrams.

Building a rich tapestry of contributors to my identity has meant not any one person or passion will have outsized expectations to fulfil and that is beautiful. My meaningful relationships can blossom while I continue to discover new and different influences. For me this new found control of identity, of how I present myself and navigate the digital realm has unlocked my sense of adventure.

The idea of showing up to a room full of people who are expertly navigating a diverse range of topics makes my palms sweat ‚Äî but observing via a Discord Chat is being a digital fly on the wall. Expressing yourself via an avatar can feel like wearing a fake moustache and glasses to a conversation ‚Äî you are covert, unrecognisable yet reaping the full benefits of the interaction. It isn‚Äôt about hiding, it is about having access and choice and ultimately control.

There is so much discussion swirling around web3, a lot of noise about NFTs and an entirely new vocabulary branching off of *decentralised*. Where we will land I do not know but it is not likely to be Earnest Cline‚Äôs Ready Player One or George Orwell‚Äôs 1984 in our lifetime.

If you, like me, are suffering an identity crisis then I recommend getting out there! Create an avatar on Genies. Join a discord chat, if you‚Äôre a sneakerhead check out Adidas Originals or for a great, female-led entrepreneurial group BFF. Make pizza in Roblox and roam Decentraland. Follow Snoop-Dogg on Twitter. Get familiar with mirror.xyz journalism. Create your ENS name.

Have fun with the different ways you can be you.

It is not unreal to explore new things, it is not inauthentic to be many things. It is entirely human and more than ever technology is enabling our innate sense of exploration and expansion.

Tell you something about myself, where do I even start!

title: Roe vs Wade and your period data - who is in control?
body:
**If you felt uneasy seeing the suspicious Instagram ad for car upholstery minutes after discussing it then have you considered how your health data can be leveraged in a post Roe vs Wade world?**

Like 43 million other people around the world I use Flo to monitor my periods. I use it because I like knowing more about my body, like when I can expect my period or why my face is having a throwback to 90s acne fashion.

I also joined more than 290 million people in 2021 and bought myself a wearable. Not just any wearable, I wanted the Garmin sports watch that revealed data I‚Äôd never even heard of. I wanted so much data that I had to spend more time searching for metric definitions than reading the data itself.

I never take my watch off. I sleep with it on so I can use the data to inform how I should feel when I wake up. I have literally outsourced my feelings to technology.

Never did I once stop to think about how all this health data could be used against me. Akin to requesting my medical history, what is stopping my health insurance provider from requesting my watch data and what happens if I say no (can I even say no?).

Trawling Twitter I came across the [Mashable](https://mashable.com/article/period-apps-roe-v-wade) article *Period Apps in a Post-Roe World*. I was truly startled by the question - who owns my period data. I had never questioned it but now that data could be weaponised against women and I feel scared.

I feel scared because we‚Äôve been indoctrinated into a world of technology and regulation as trusting.

We‚Äôve blindly outsourced control and when it turned against us we assumed regulators and legislators could step in to rescue us. That has largely not worked. We‚Äôre disrupted by a variety of unstandardised data pop-ups at the most inopportune times that make saying no hard. Now we‚Äôre facing legislation that is removing choice altogether.

In 2011 South Park released HUMANCENTiPAD which depicts the bleakest of outcomes when we don‚Äôt read our T&Cs. After this, for the shortest time, I read my T&Cs but they‚Äôre very boring and the vernacular makes me feel stupid. It is unpleasant in enough ways that the memory of HUMANCENTiPAD dissipated and I went back to blind acceptance.

In 2018 there was excitement around wearables as a tool to intercept medical emergencies amongst the elderly. The monitoring of wearable data could enable our elderly community to lead a more independent life. I loved it. I never once stopped to think about the paradox of independence through monitoring.

In 2020 an Australia court [forced Google](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/feb/14/court-says-melbourne-dentist-can-serve-google-for-user-details-over-bad-review) to reveal the identity of an anonymous user who left a negative review of a Dentistry, and in 2022 [forced Twitter](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jun/07/twitter-ordered-to-hand-over-prguy17s-personal-information-as-part-of-defamation-suit) to reveal the identity of a pseudonymous account following a defamation claim. I‚Äôm not convinced the everyday social user is aware that their personal data can be solicited in this way.

Bringing us back to 2022 and we have emerging technologies enabling trustless systems and sovereign identity. It is a momentous shift and people are not flocking to this new sense of control because it is scary AF. It is intended to feel complicated, full of codified language to keep laypeople out. If I‚Äôm worried about how the Australian Government can access my personal data I‚Äôm sure as hell not ready to consider a totally anonymous tech-fluent entity as the next best option.

It is hard not to hark back to South Park‚Äôs 2004 Douche and Turd episode. By that I mean we‚Äôre faced with less than ideal options and it can feel hopeless. By no means do I want people to feel that way. New technologies are not ready for full-on adoption and old technologies are so ingrained that total disconnection is near impossible.

Instead I say it is time we got a little curious about data storage. I think it is unreasonable to read all your T&Cs and a world without all this amazing technology would suck. But, you should know where your data is stored to understand what laws protect you as a user.

For example, if your data is stored in Europe, like the users of Flo, then you are protected by some of the most advanced digital and data legislation in the world such as GDPR and the Digital Services Act. At the very least get familiar with who makes the big decisions in your country and how that extends to you. For example, GDPR protects the processing of data for all EU residents regardless of where they live.

By knowing who governs your data and how apps can use it means you are more empowered to make choices that favour your rights. I implore you to take this small step towards control in our tech interfaced world. Start with the apps you use the most, the ones that know the most about you or access the most personal of your data.

Our internet is full of variety and choice, you can always find a better solution to suit all your needs including privacy. Or, if not build one. You as the user have the power and you don‚Äôt need to settle.

PS - if like me your T&Cs still scare you, or if you just watched HUMANCENTiPAD then <https://tosdr.org/> might come in handy.

ÏàúÏàòÌïòÍ≤å Web 3.0 Ïï†ÌîåÎ¶¨ÏºÄÏù¥ÏÖòÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê ÎøêÎßå ÏïÑÎãàÎùº ÎÑ§Ìä∏ÏõåÌÅ¨ ÏÑ±Ïû•Ïóê Í∏∞Ïó¨ÌïòÎäî Ï¥àÍ∏∞ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ Ï†ÑÌÜµÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÎπÑÏ¶àÎãàÏä§ Í∞úÎ∞úÏù¥ÎÇò Web 2.0Ïùò ÏÑ∏ÏùºÏ¶à Îß®Îì§Î≥¥Îã§ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Î™®Ìã∞Î≤†Ïù¥ÏÖòÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÏ£†.

ÏöîÏïΩÌïòÏûêÎ©¥, Web 2.0ÏóêÏÑú GTM Ï†ÑÎûµÎ•º ÏàòÎ¶ΩÌï† Îïå Í≥†Î†§Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî ÎåÄÏÉÅÏùÄ ÏÑ∏ÏùºÏ¶à Î∞è ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ ÌöçÎìùÌïú Í≥†Í∞ùÏù¥ÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Î∞òÎ©¥, Web 3.0ÏóêÏÑúÎäî Í≥†Í∞ù, ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê ÎøêÎßå ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Í∞úÎ∞úÏûê, Ìà¨ÏûêÏûê Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÌååÌä∏ÎÑàÎèÑ Ìè¨Ìï®Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÏ£†. ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Web 3.0 ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§ÏóêÍ≤åÎäî ÏÑ∏ÏùºÏ¶àÏôÄ ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖÎ≥¥Îã§ Ïª§ÎÆ§ÎãàÌã∞Ïùò Ïó≠Ìï†Ïù¥ Îçî Ï§ëÏöîÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

# **The web3 go-to-market matrix**

![Go-to-Market in Web3: New Mindsets, Tactics, Metrics](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cNDb-n4iT-Qz5JOwXTsSK.png?height=1254&width=2000)

‚ÄòGo To Market‚Äô Ï†ÑÎûµÏùÄ Í∞Å ÏÇ¨Î∂ÑÎ©¥Ïóê Îî∞Îùº Îã¨ÎùºÏßÄÎ©∞, Í∏∞Ï°¥Ïùò Web 2.0 Ïä§ÌÉÄÏùºÏùò GTM Ï†ÑÎûµÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏÉàÎ°≠Í≥† Ïã§ÌóòÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ï†ÑÎûµÍπåÏßÄ Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ìè¨Ìï®Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑúÎäî 1ÏÇ¨Î∂ÑÎ©¥(Decentralized with Token)Ïóê Ï¥àÏ†êÏùÑ ÎßûÏ∂îÍ≥†, 3ÏÇ¨Î∂ÑÎ©¥(Centralized with No Token)Í≥º ÎπÑÍµêÌïòÏó¨, Web 3.0Í≥º Web 2.0Ïùò GTM Ï†ÑÎûµ Ï∞®Ïù¥Ï†êÏùÑ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù ÌïòÍ≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

title: The Future Of Futures: Is Tsunami taking crypto to new levels?
body:
The universe of crypto as we know, is ever changing and the excitement never seems to end! I can tell you by experience, since 2016 when I first entered, almost nothing is the same. New innovations and projects continue to change finance as we know it, and Tsunami is the newest one to do it.

I welcome you all to Tsunami Token. Built on the Waves Blockchain with a total supply of only 1 Million, Tsunami (TSN) aims to be the first of its kind to enable decentralized Perpetual Futures on the blockchain! A successful testnet was also completed with a turnout of +3500 participants. In partnership with Puzzle.surf, Tsunami began an explosive ILO! Upon the market becoming live, Tsunami shot out of the gate. Investors were in disbelief as the token jumped from $0.20 to $5.00 and eventually settled around $3.00. Within hours, Tsunami had a $3,000,000 market cap! Currently, the token is sitting at $4.90. If this is any indication of what‚Äôs to come, it‚Äôs that Tsunami will take us all by storm!

Now onto expanding on what Tsunami has to offer, it‚Äôs quite the change of pace in crypto. Perpetual Futures on the blockchain. Futures contracts can have any token paired against each other while traders bet on the future price. Doing so and placing their positions by adding liquid to the market, portions of this goes into the Funding Rate, which incentivizes traders to keep the market price as close to the index price as possible. There is potential for extreme profits in Futures as you have leverage at your disposal. Leverage is the use of borrowed capital to multiply your earnings and that is where the vAMM comes into play. Tsunami has what you call a virtual Automated Market Maker or vAMM that provides polymerized leverage to the market. Its essential roles are price discovery and leverage up to 10x what you have invested. Of course this can work in your favor or against you, depending on your position and market conditions. Price swings surrounding cryptocurrency is no secret. By bringing futures into the mix of highly volatile markets and major price swings, it will be quite a sight to see once Tsunamis exchange goes live!

Lastly, I would like to mention that Tsunami holders will also have the opportunity to stake their TSN. Acquire more TSN for simply not selling the ones you already have! Its a great way for Tsunami to hold its value while investors gain a commission for not selling them. Staking will also allow you the benefit to help shape and form Tsunami as a whole with your very own suggestions, opinions and insights. Own some Tsunami? You have a say. I also understand that Tsunami isn‚Äôt stopping here and will be bringing new products down the line. We will have to patiently wait and see what they bring to the table next!

Will Tsunami take the crypto universe by storm? Only time will tell but my thoughts are leaning towards yes! Do you agree? I‚Äôll be writing more about this Token in the future and as always, Thanks for reading!
